screens.headline: You finished the course... but your broker won't let you trade spreads
screens.text: Imagine learning 50 lessons, ready to execute your first iron condor, and your broker says 'Options Level 1 account - spreads not approved.' This happens to THOUSANDS of beginners. Let's make sure you pick the right broker from day one.

screens.headline: Why Broker Choice Matters
screens.text: Not all brokers are equal for options. Key differences: OPTIONS APPROVAL LEVELS (1-5), commissions ($0-0.65/contract), platform quality (mobile vs desktop), customer service, and approval speed. Pick wrong = can't execute strategies you learned. Pick right = smooth trading experience.

cards.definition: 1 = Covered calls only. 2 = Buying options. 3 = Spreads. 4 = Naked puts. 5 = Naked calls
cards.example: Level 1 = can't do CSPs. Level 3 = can do 90% of strategies. Start at Level 2-3.

cards.definition: Per-contract fee on every option trade (both entry and exit)
cards.example: Webull: $0. TD Ameritrade: $0.65/contract. 10 contracts = $13 round trip at TD vs $0 at Webull.

cards.definition: If <$25K account, limited to 3 day trades per 5 days
cards.example: Buy and sell same option same day = 1 day trade. 4th trade in 5 days = account locked for 90 days!

cards.definition: How broker handles expiration and early assignment
cards.example: Some brokers auto-close ITM options at 3pm Friday. Others let them expire. Know your broker's policy!

screens.headline: Think of brokers like gyms
screens.text: You want to get fit (trade options)...

reveal_sections.label: Planet Fitness (Robinhood)
reveal_sections.content: Cheap/free, basic equipment (limited strategies), crowded (order flow issues), beginners everywhere. Good for starting but you'll outgrow it fast. Approval process slow.

reveal_sections.label: LA Fitness (Webull, Schwab)
reveal_sections.content: Mid-tier, good equipment (most strategies), reasonable price, solid for most people. Best balance for intermediate traders. Approval in 1-3 days.

reveal_sections.label: Equinox (TD Ameritrade, Interactive Brokers)
reveal_sections.content: Premium, every tool imaginable, costs more ($0.65/contract), professional-grade platform. For serious/active traders. Instant approval for qualified accounts.

screens.headline: Broker Comparison Tool
screens.description: Compare costs and features across brokers
teaching_points: For active traders, commissions matter. For beginners, $0 is better.

screens.question: You want to sell cash-secured puts and covered calls. What minimum options approval level do you need?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Level 2 covers both covered calls AND cash-secured puts (selling puts). Level 1 = only covered calls. Level 3 = adds spreads. Level 4 = naked puts. Most brokers grant Level 2 easily - just answer application honestly about income/experience.
screens.explanation_wrong: Covered calls + CSPs = Level 2 at most brokers. Level 1 = covered calls only (can't do CSPs). When applying, request Level 2 minimum. Some brokers auto-approve Level 2, others need 1-3 days. Don't undersell your experience on application!

screens.question: You have $8,000 account. You want to day trade options (buy and sell same day). What happens?
options: 3 day trades per 5 trading days (PDT rule)
Cannot day trade at all with <$25K
Must pay $5 fee per day trade
screens.explanation_correct: That's the PDT rule! <$25K account = max 3 day trades in any 5-day rolling period. 4th trade = account locked for 90 days. Trade #1 Monday, #2 Wednesday, #3 Friday = used up. Can't day trade again until next Monday. With $8K, avoid day trading or save up to $25K!
screens.explanation_wrong: Pattern Day Trader rule: <$25K = max 3 day trades per 5 trading days. Day trade = buy AND sell same option same day. Holding overnight = not a day trade. 4th day trade in 5 days = 90-day trading restriction. Either trade overnight or save to $25K!

screens.question: Best broker for absolute beginners (first 30 days)?
options: TD Ameritrade - professional platform but complex
Interactive Brokers - lowest costs but steep learning curve
Webull or Schwab - free commissions, user-friendly, good mobile apps
Robinhood - simplest interface but limited features
screens.explanation_correct: Great choice! Webull/Schwab = sweet spot for beginners. $0 commissions, clean mobile apps, good educational content, most strategies available, easy approval. Start here, graduate to TD/IB if you become very active. Robinhood too limited (slow approvals, limited spreads).
screens.explanation_wrong: Webull or Schwab hit the balance: free commissions (save $1000+/year), user-friendly, mobile-first, quick approval, customer service. TD = amazing platform but $0.65/contract adds up. IB = complex UI. Robinhood = too limited (no spreads on many tickers). Start Webull/Schwab.

screens.question: It's 3:50pm expiration Friday. Your $50 call is ITM (stock at $52). You forgot to close it. What might happen?
options: Depends on broker policy - CHECK THIS!
screens.explanation_correct: CRITICAL! Some brokers (Robinhood, Webull) auto-close ITM options at 3pm Friday. Others (TD, Schwab) let them auto-exercise. You could wake up Monday owning 100 shares worth $5,200 (need $5,200 cash!). ALWAYS know your broker's policy and close manually before 4pm Friday!
screens.explanation_wrong: Broker policies vary wildly! Some force-close at 3pm Friday. Some exercise ITM options automatically. Some let you choose. CHECK YOUR BROKER'S POLICY before expiration week! Best practice: always close manually before 4pm Friday. Don't rely on auto-anything!

screens.question: You're applying for options approval. Application asks 'years of experience.' You have 6 months of paper trading. What do you say?
options: 1-2 years - paper trading counts as experience
5+ years - lie to get approved faster
screens.explanation_correct: Smart honesty! Paper trading = real experience. 6 months paper trading = '1 year' is fair. Brokers want to see you're not completely new. Saying '0 years' after completing this course = underselling yourself. Saying '5+ years' = fraud. 1-2 years paper trading + education = honest and approvable!
screens.explanation_wrong: Don't undersell OR oversell. Paper trading + education = legitimate experience. Brokers reject 'complete beginners' but approve 'some experience.' After this course + paper trading = honestly say '1-2 years experience with options education.' You're not lying - you ARE educated! Gets Level 2-3 approval.

cards.back: Webull or Charles Schwab. Both: $0 commissions, Level 2-3 approval, mobile-friendly, good customer service. Start here. Upgrade to TD/IB later if you trade 500+ contracts/month.

cards.front: What approval level do I need?
cards.back: Level 2 minimum (covered calls + CSPs + buying options). Level 3 if you want spreads (recommended). Request Level 2-3 on application. Most brokers approve in 1-3 business days.

cards.front: What about Pattern Day Trader rule?
cards.back: <$25K = max 3 day trades per 5 trading days. Day trade = buy AND sell same option same day. Avoid day trading until $25K+ account OR hold positions overnight. 4th trade = 90-day restriction!
